summary: Email correspondence between legal professionals discussing the extradition of a dual French-US national from France, specifically in the context of the Maxwell/Epstein matter. The email explains that French law prohibits the extradition of French nationals, with a possible exception if nationality was acquired after the alleged criminal conduct.

persons.name: Assistant United States Attorney
persons.context: The AUSA from the Southern District of New York is seeking legal advice regarding the extradition process in France for the Maxwell/Epstein matter.

events.title: Legal Consultation on French Extradition
events.description: Email exchange where a legal expert provides analysis to an AUSA on the improbability of extraditing a dual French-US national from France, citing French law and the bilateral extradition treaty.

locations: One Saint Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY 10007
keyFacts: French law (Article 696-4 of the French Criminal Procedure Code) prohibits the extradition of French nationals.
The bilateral extradition treaty between the US and France does not obligate France to extradite its nationals.
A possible exception exists if the individual acquired French nationality after the period of the alleged criminal conduct, but this is noted as a rare case.
The correspondence is in the context of the Maxwell/Epstein matter being handled by the Southern District of New York.
An attached memorandum discusses advance waivers of extradition as a potential bail condition, though it is noted to be a few years out of date.
